name: 1598_C. Delete Two Elements
description:
Monocarp has got an array a consisting of n integers. Let's denote k as the mathematic mean of these elements (note that it's possible that k is not an integer). 

The mathematic mean of an array of n elements is the sum of elements divided by the number of these elements (i. e. sum divided by n).

Monocarp wants to delete exactly two elements from a so that the mathematic mean of the remaining (n - 2) elements is still equal to k.

Your task is to calculate the number of pairs of positions [i, j] (i < j) such that if the elements on these positions are deleted, the mathematic mean of (n - 2) remaining elements is equal to k (that is, it is equal to the mathematic mean of n elements of the original array a).

Input

The first line contains a single integer t (1 ≤ t ≤ 10^4) — the number of testcases.

The first line of each testcase contains one integer n (3 ≤ n ≤ 2 ⋅ 10^5) — the number of elements in the array.

The second line contains a sequence of integers a_1, a_2, ..., a_n (0 ≤ a_i ≤ 10^{9}), where a_i is the i-th element of the array.

The sum of n over all testcases doesn't exceed 2 ⋅ 10^5.

Output

Print one integer — the number of pairs of positions [i, j] (i < j) such that if the elements on these positions are deleted, the mathematic mean of (n - 2) remaining elements is equal to k (that is, it is equal to the mathematic mean of n elements of the original array a).

Example

Input


4
4
8 8 8 8
3
50 20 10
5
1 4 7 3 5
7
1 2 3 4 5 6 7


Output


6
0
2
3

Note

In the first example, any pair of elements can be removed since all of them are equal.

In the second example, there is no way to delete two elements so the mathematic mean doesn't change.

In the third example, it is possible to delete the elements on positions 1 and 3, or the elements on positions 4 and 5.

The mathematic mean of an array of n elements is the sum of elements divided by n. This value provides a measure of the central tendency of the array. It is a fundamental concept in mathematics and statistics.

Monocarp wants to delete exactly two elements from a so that the mathematic mean of the remaining (n - 2) elements is still equal to k.

Your task is to calculate the number of pairs of positions [i, j] (i < j) such that if the elements on these positions are deleted, the mathematic mean of (n - 2) remaining elements is equal to the mathematic mean of n elements of the original array a.

The first line contains a single integer t (1 ≤ t ≤ 10^4) — the number of testcases.

The first line of each testcase contains one integer n (3 ≤ n ≤ 2 ⋅ 10^5) — the number of elements in the array.

The second line contains a sequence of integers a_1, a_2, ..., a_n (0 ≤ a_i ≤ 10^{9}), where a_i is the i-th element of the array.

The sum of n over all testcases doesn't exceed 2 ⋅ 10^5.

Output

Print one integer — the number of pairs of positions [i, j] (i < j) such that if the elements on these positions are deleted, the mathematic mean of (n - 2) remaining elements is equal to k (that is, it is equal to the mathematic mean of n elements of the original array a).

Monocarp has an array a with n elements. The mean of these elements, denoted as k, is calculated by dividing the sum of all elements by n. This average value is a key concept in both mathematics and statistics, representing the central tendency of the data.

Monocarp wants to remove exactly two elements from the array a, and he wants the mean of the remaining (n - 2) elements to be the same as the original mean k.

Input

The first line contains a single integer t (1 ≤ t ≤ 10^4) — the number of testcases.

The first line of each testcase contains one integer n (3 ≤ n ≤ 2 ⋅ 10^5) — the number of elements in the array.

The second line contains a sequence of integers a_1, a_2, ..., a_n (0 ≤ a_i ≤ 10^{9}), where a_i is the i-th element of the array.

The sum of n over all testcases doesn't exceed 2 ⋅ 10^5.

Output

Print one integer — the number of pairs of positions [i, j] (i < j) such that if the elements on these positions are deleted, the mathematic mean of (n - 2) remaining elements is equal to k (that is, it is equal to the mathematic mean of n elements of the original array a).

-------
Important Note: You must follow the input output format. Input must be taken from standard input and output must be given to standard output. The code will be tested against multiple test cases and all the test cases must be passed.
Example

Input


4
4
8 8 8 8
3
50 20 10
5
1 4 7 3 5
7
1 2 3 4 5 6 7


Output


6
0
2
3

Note

In the first example, any pair of elements can be removed since all of them are equal.

In the second example, there is no way to delete two elements so the mathematic mean doesn't change.

In the third example, it is possible to delete the elements on positions 1 and 3, or the elements on positions 4 and 5.
Write a main() function and use input() function to read input from stdin

Monocarp has an array a of n integers, and k is the mean of these elements. He wants to delete two elements from a so that the mean of the remaining (n - 2) elements is still k. Calculate the number of pairs [i, j] (i < j) such that deleting the elements at these positions keeps the mean of the remaining elements equal to the original mean k.

Input

The first line contains a single integer t (1 ≤ t ≤ 10^4) — the number of testcases.

The first line of each testcase contains one integer n (3 ≤ n ≤ 2 ⋅ 10^5) — the number of elements in the array.

The second line contains a sequence of integers a_1, a_2, ..., a_n (0 ≤ a_i ≤ 10^{9}), where a_i is the i-th element of the array.

The sum of n over all testcases doesn't exceed 2 ⋅ 10^5.

Output

Print one integer — the number of pairs of positions [i, j] (i < j) such that if the elements on these positions are deleted, the mathematic mean of (n - 2) remaining elements is equal to k (that is, it is equal to the mathematic mean of n elements of the original array a).

-------
Important Note: You must follow the input output format. Input must be taken from standard input and output must be given to standard output. The code will be tested against multiple test cases and all the test cases must be passed.

Input

Output

Note

In the first example, any pair of elements can be removed since all of them are equal.

In the second example, there is no way to delete two elements so the mathematic mean doesn't change.

completions:
from typing import List
from typing import List

def calculate_pairs(n: int, arr: List[int]) -> int:
    total_sum = sum(arr)
    mean = total_sum / n
    
    result = 0
    for i in range(n):
        for j in range(i + 1, n):
            if i != j:
                new_sum = total_sum - arr[i] - arr[j]
                new_mean = new_sum / (n - 2)
                if new_mean == mean:
                    result += 1
    return result

# Provide the Interface
n = int(input())
arr = list(map(int, input().split()))
result = calculate_pairs(n, arr)
print(result)
from typing import List
## main.py

def calculate_pairs(n, arr):
    """
    Calculate the number of pairs [i, j] such that deleting the elements at these positions results in the mean of the remaining elements being equal to the original mean.

    Args:
        n (int): The number of elements in the array.
        arr (list): The list of integers representing the array.

    Returns:
        int: The number of pairs [i, j] that satisfy the condition.
    """
    total_sum = sum(arr)
    original_mean = total_sum / n

    count = 0
    for i in range(n):
        for j in range(i + 1, n):
            if i != j:
                new_sum = total_sum - arr[i] - arr[j]
                new_mean = new_sum / (n - 2)
                if new_mean == original_mean:
                    count += 1
    return count

# Read input
t = int(input())
for _ in range(t):
    n = int(input())
    arr = list(map(int, input().split()))
    result = calculate_pairs(n, arr)
    print(result)
from typing import List
from typing import List

def calculate_pairs_of_positions(n: int, arr: List[int]) -> int:
    # Calculate the mean of the entire array
    total_sum = sum(arr)
    mean = total_sum / n
    
    # Initialize the count of valid pairs
    count = 0
    
    # Iterate through all possible pairs [i, j] where i < j
    for i in range(n):
        for j in range(i + 1, n):
            # Check if deleting the elements at positions i and j maintains the mean
            if (total_sum - arr[i] - arr[j]) / (n - 2) == mean:
                count += 1
    
    return count

# Provide the Interface
t = int(input())
for _ in range(t):
    n = int(input())
    arr = list(map(int, input().split()))
    result = calculate_pairs_of_positions(n, arr)
    print(result)
from typing import List
from typing import List

def calculate_mean_and_pairs(n: int, arr: List[int]) -> int:
    # Calculate the original mean of the array
    original_mean = sum(arr) / n
    
    # Initialize the count of valid pairs
    count = 0
    
    # Iterate through all possible pairs of elements in the array
    for i in range(n):
        for j in range(i + 1, n):
            # Create a new array excluding the elements at indices i and j
            new_arr = arr[:i] + arr[i+1:j] + arr[j+1:]
            
            # Calculate the mean of the new array
            if len(new_arr) > 0:
                new_mean = sum(new_arr) / len(new_arr)
                
                # Check if the new mean is equal to the original mean
                if new_mean == original_mean:
                    count += 1
    
    return count

# Provide the Interface
t = int(input())
results = []
for _ in range(t):
    n = int(input())
    arr = list(map(int, input().split()))
    result = calculate_mean_and_pairs(n, arr)
    results.append(result)
for result in results:
    print(result)
from typing import List
from typing import List

def calculate_mean_pairs(n: int, arr: List[int]) -> int:
    # Calculate the original mean
    total_sum = sum(arr)
    original_mean = total_sum / n
    
    # Count the frequency of each element
    frequency = {}
    for num in arr:
        frequency[num] = frequency.get(num, 0) + 1
    
    # Initialize the count of valid pairs
    valid_pairs_count = 0
    
    # Iterate through the array to find valid pairs
    for i in range(n):
        for j in range(i + 1, n):
            # Remove the elements at positions i and j
            new_arr = arr[:i] + arr[i+1:j] + arr[j+1:]
            new_sum = sum(new_arr)
            new_n = n - 2
            if new_n > 0 and new_sum / new_n == original_mean:
                valid_pairs_count += 1
    
    return valid_pairs_count

# Provide the Interface
n = int(input())
arr = list(map(int, input().split()))
result = calculate_mean_pairs(n, arr)
print(result)
from typing import List
## main.py
from typing import List

def calculate_mean_and_pairs(n: int, arr: List[int]) -> int:
    original_mean = sum(arr) / n
    count = 0
    element_count = {}
    
    # Count the occurrences of each element
    for num in arr:
        if num in element_count:
            element_count[num] += 1
        else:
            element_count[num] = 1
    
    # Iterate through the element counts to find valid pairs
    for num, freq in element_count.items():
        if freq > num:
            count += freq - num
        elif freq < num:
            count += freq
    
    return count

# Provide the Interface
t = int(input())
for _ in range(t):
    n = int(input())
    arr = list(map(int, input().split()))
    result = calculate_mean_and_pairs(n, arr)
    print(result)

def calculate_pairs(n, arr):
    total_sum = sum(arr)
    k = total_sum / n
    
    if n < 3:
        return 0
    
    count = 0
    for i in range(n):
        for j in range(i + 1, n):
            if i != j:
                new_sum = total_sum - arr[i] - arr[j]
                new_mean = new_sum / (n - 2)
                if new_mean == k:
                    count += 1
    return count

# Provide the Interface
t = int(input())
for _ in range(t):
    n = int(input())
    arr = list(map(int, input().split()))
    result = calculate_pairs(n, arr)
    print(result)

## main.py
from typing import List

def calculate_pairs_to_maintain_mean(n: int, arr: List[int]) -> int:
    # Calculate the original mean of the array
    original_mean = sum(arr) / n
    
    # Initialize the count of pairs
    count = 0
    
    # Calculate the sum of all elements in the array
    total_sum = sum(arr)
    
    # Use a set to store the indices of elements that can be deleted to maintain the mean
    valid_pairs = set()
    
    # Iterate through all possible pairs of indices [i, j] where i < j
    for i in range(n):
        for j in range(i + 1, n):
            # Calculate the sum of the remaining elements after deleting elements at positions i and j
            remaining_sum = total_sum - arr[i] - arr[j]
            remaining_count = n - 2
            
            # Check if the mean of the remaining elements is equal to the original mean
            if remaining_sum / remaining_count == original_mean:
                # Store the pair as a tuple in the set to avoid duplicates
                valid_pairs.add((i, j))
    
    # The number of valid pairs is the size of the set
    return len(valid_pairs)

# Provide the Interface
t = int(input())
for _ in range(t):
    n = int(input())
    arr = list(map(int, input().split()))
    result = calculate_pairs_to_maintain_mean(n, arr)
    print(result)

            if len(new_arr) > 0 and sum(new_arr) / len(new_arr) == original_mean:
                count += 1

    return count

# Provide the Interface

for _ in range(t):
    n = int(input())
    arr = list(map(int, input().split()))
    result = calculate_pairs_of_positions(n, arr)
    print(result)

# [edge case] 
    Edge case 1: All elements are the same.
    Edge case 2: No pair of elements can be removed to maintain the original mean.
    Edge case 3: The array has a single unique element.

# [extra code for edge case]
    We need extra code to handle the edge cases where all elements are the same or the array has a single unique element.
    For edge case 1: If all elements are the same, any pair can be removed, so the number of pairs is n * (n - 1) / 2.
    For edge case 2 and 3: We need to check if removing any pair of elements changes the mean. If not, we skip those cases.

 # [core concept]
    'mathematic mean': The average value of a set of numbers, calculated by dividing the sum of the numbers by the count of the numbers.
    Explanation: The mathematic mean is a fundamental concept in statistics and mathematics, representing the central tendency of a set of numbers. In this problem, Monocarp wants to delete two elements from the array such that the mean of the remaining elements remains the same as the original mean.

# [phrase showing quantity relationship]
    'more than': Indicates that the number of times a number appears must be greater than or equal to the number itself.
    Explanation: For example, if the number is 3, it must appear at least 3 times in the array.

# [degree adverb] 
    'largest': Indicates that we need to find the largest number that meets the condition.
    Explanation: In the requirement, we need to find the largest integer that appears at least as many times as itself.

# [code logic]
    To solve this problem, we need to follow these steps:
    1. Calculate the original mean of the array.
    2. Iterate through all possible pairs of indices (i, j) where i < j.
    3. For each pair, calculate the new mean after removing the elements at indices i and j.
    4. Check if the new mean is equal to the original mean.
    5. Count the number of such pairs.

# [edge case] 
    search([1, 2, 3, 4, 5]) = 0
    Explanation: In this case, there are no pairs of elements that can be deleted to maintain the original mean, so the expected output is 0.
    search([2, 2, 2, 2]) = 6
    Explanation: All elements are the same, so any pair of elements can be deleted to maintain the original mean. There are 6 possible pairs (0-1, 0-2, 0-3, 1-2, 1-3, 2-3).

# [extra code for edge case]
    We do not need extra code to handle the edge case. The logic provided in the plan is sufficient to handle the edge case where no pairs can maintain the original mean.
examples:
Input

The first line contains a single integer t (1 ≤ t ≤ 10^4) — the number of testcases.

The first line of each testcase contains one integer n (3 ≤ n ≤ 2 ⋅ 10^5) — the number of elements in the array.

The second line contains a sequence of integers a_1, a_2, ..., a_n (0 ≤ a_i ≤ 10^{9}), where a_i is the i-th element of the array.

The sum of n over all testcases doesn't exceed 2 ⋅ 10^5.

Output

Print one integer — the number of pairs of positions [i, j] (i < j) such that if the elements on these positions are deleted, the mathematic mean of (n - 2) remaining elements is equal to k (that is, it is equal to the mathematic mean of n elements of the original array a).

Example

Input


4
4
8 8 8 8
3
50 20 10
5
1 4 7 3 5
7
1 2 3 4 5 6 7


Output


6
0
2
3

Note

In the first example, any pair of elements can be removed since all of them are equal.

In the second example, there is no way to delete two elements so the mathematic mean doesn't change.

In the third example, it is possible to delete the elements on positions 1 and 3, or the elements on positions 4 and 5.
